dialogues.text: Maybe nobody cared. Maybe they cared too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky cruises by the crime scene. Rubberneckers gawk arou the vacant lot while vendors peddle greasy food and cheap portrait glossies of the Dahlia in a black dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky sits at his desk staring at RAYMOND NASH'S MUGSHOT.

dialogues.speaker: HIS EYES DRIFT TO
dialogues.text: A WAGER POOL SIGN-UP LIST POSTED ON THE WALL: a crude fel craps table with various betting spaces: "Solved--2 to 1" "Random Sex Job--4 to 1", "Uhsolved--Even Money", "Boyfriend(s)--l to 4"... Next to it are TWO HALVES OF A BLACK DRESS on separate hangers...a crude joke. Bucky opens up his desk drawer and drops the Nash mugshot inside. He dials the phone: BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Administrative Vice Squad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky pulls his car up to a low-slung building with a log cabin facade and swinging Western doors. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dimly lit LESBIAN BAR. Butch women in GI khakis mix wit soft girls in cashmere skirt suits. Bucky approaches a bartender. The woman sizes him up and slides him a whiskey. BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverage Control? BUCKY (downing the whiskey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAPD Homicide. BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who got snuffed? Bucky slides her a photo of the Dahlia and Linda Martin's BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen either of 'em? BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. The Dahlia's a sister? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me. BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never seen her 'cept in the papers. And the little schoolgirl twist I've never seen. We don't truck with underaged stuff. Capice? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capice when your girls tell me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the photos are passed from patron to patron. Aside fro few raised eyebrows over the Dahlia, nothing to indicate anyone knows anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time an Olde English motif. Bucky sips another free whiskey as a dozen more women pass the photos around. Buc watches their reactions closely but doesn't see anything of the ordinary. He takes another shot of whiskey and heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tropical motif. Faux bamboo wrap-around booths shield w snuggled deep into the dark corners. A bit buzzed and embarrassed to have to go booth to booth break up couples, Bucky slowly makes his way around the b with the two photos. More of the same... He approaches a woman polishing glasses at the bar. Slide over the photos. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black Dahlia. BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit. He taps a finger onto Linda Martin's ID. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about this girl? The bartender picks up the card and squints at it. Bucky a flicker of recognition in her eyes. She hesitates-- BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never seen her. He leans over the counter. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you fuckin' lie to me. She's fifteen fucking years old. So you come clean or I slap a contributing beef on you, and you spend the next five years servin' raisinjack to bulldykes in Tehachapi. The bartender looks again at the ID card. BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple times. Two, three months ago. Just to cadge drinks off the sisters, though. She liked boys, I'm sure. And not the Dahlia. Never. Out of his peripheral vision Bucky sees another woman jus starting to sit down on a bar stool but at the last minut change her mind and make for the door. A baby spotlight catches her face; a fleeting resemblance Elizabeth Short. Bucky takes a deep breath, counts to ten and then goes ou after the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman gets into a beautiful snow-white Packard.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS OF VARIOUS STREETS
dialogues.text: as Bucky tails the white Packard from three car-lengths b He follows her all the way from the Valley to Hancock Par

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the woman parks her car in front of A HUGE TUDOR MANSI Bucky cruises by, catching her license plate and writing on a pack of matches from LaVerne's. In his rear view mirror he sees her exit the car, a strik figure in a sharkskin suit. He watches her walk up the enormous lawn and into the home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky reads the license plate into the phone. He receives information back and writes it onto the matchbook, as wel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky lies in his bed, staring at the ceiling. His bedsid light reveals a still life: Elizabeth Short's mug shot ph tucked underneath the matchbook. The cover is flipped ope and we can see written: "Madeleine Cathcart Sprague".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky's listening to The Dexter Gordon quartet on the rad when the tune is interrupted by a feverish voice: ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We interrupt our regular broadcast to bring you a bulletin. A major suspect in the investigation of Elizabeth Short, the raven-haired beauty known as the Black Dahlia, has been captured! Red Manley, a Huntington Park hardware salesman and one of the last men to be seen with the Dahlia, was captured early this morning. Currently being held at Hollenback Station-- Bucky takes a quick left down another street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky runs into Lee as he enters the station. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dahlia left San Diego six days before we found her. Dago cops got a witness puts her in a tan Dodge with a partial plate ident. Finally got a cross-check that matched on Red here. INT. OUTSIDE THE INTERROGATION ROOM - CONT. Seems like every cop in town has jammed themselves into a small corridor, watching Russ Millard interrogate RED MAN through a one way mirror. Manley is carrot-topped, 25, an scared shitless. Millard's soothing voice can be heard through speakers. MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, Robert. We're doing this because you didn't come forward. RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told it three times now. I didn't want my wife to know I was chipping her. MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said you didn't chip on her. Betty wouldn't put out. That's no reason to hide from the police. RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dated her down in Dago. I slow-danced with her. It's the same thing as chipping. MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you wanted to fuck her, didn't you? RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted...to test my loyalty to my wife. MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, son! RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to fuck her. Yes. MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she cock-teased you. RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said she had her period-- All of the cops outside laugh. RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said the father of her child would be a combat veteran-- MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you were in the Army band. You get angry? RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. I didn't kill her. MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drove her back to LA with you on...December tenth? And dropped her at the Biltmore Hotel? RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told it how many ways? How many more ways do you went to hear it? Millard straightens up and turns to the one-way mirror. H tugs at the knot of his tie. Soon after he slips out of t room and Harry Sears slips in. Bucky turns to Lee. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back to earth, partner. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your fault, really. After you left Kay slipped me a Mickey. Slept for seventeen hours. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your fault for buying her all those chemistry classes. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learn anything interesting? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. LEE (re the interrogation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you'll see why Russ keeps Harry around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry circles Red Manley, lightly tapping a metal-studded in his hand. LEE (re the sap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ's only rule. No actual hitting.

dialogues.speaker: BACK INSIDE THE INTERROGATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Harry leans close to Red, tapping the sap on the table. H stutter completely gone. HARRY SEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted some fresh gash, and you thought Betty was easy. You came on strong and that didn't work. You offered her money. She told you she was on the rag, and that was the final straw. You wanted to make her bleed for real-- RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no. Not Betty-- Harry SMASHES the sap onto a glass ashtray, shattering it Red bites down on his lip, cutting it. HARRY SEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You plied Betty with drinks, got her to talk about her old boyfriends and came on like a pal, like the nice little corporal willing to leave Betty to the real men, the men who saw combat-- RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-- Harry SMASHES the table again. HARRY SEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took her to a toolshed, maybe one of those abandoned warehouses out by the old Ford plant in Pico-Rivera. There was some twine and lots of cutting tools lying around, and you got a hard-on... RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no-- Again Harry smashes the table. Red almost topples his cha backwards out of fear, only Harry's hand an the back slat keeping it from going over... HARRY SEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Reddy, yes. You thought of every girl who said "I don't suck", every time your mommy spanked you, every evil eye you got from real soldiers when you played your trombone in the army band. RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-- HARRY SEARS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldbrick, needle-nick, pussy-whipped-- RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-- HARRY SEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Betty had to pay for wasn't it? RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please! God as my witness! HARRY SEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God hates liars! Smash! HARRY SEARS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Red! Tell Betty! Tell God! RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hurt her-- HARRY SEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell God! Harry smashes the sap down the table once more and then h the whole thing over onto its side. Red fumbles out of the chair onto his knees. He clasps hi hands together-- RED MANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want... He begins to weep. Completely broken. Harry turns to the one way mirror, looking straight out a his audience: self-loathing etched into his flabby, juicehound face. He gives the thumbs-down sign and walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE IN THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Russ Millard meets him at the door and leads him away fro the general crowd of officers.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE INTERROGATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Bucky watches as Lee and another officer handcuff Red and take him outside. Lee has his hand on Red's shoulder like kindly uncle.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE STATION
dialogues.text: Bucky stands on the steps, taking fresh air. Russ steps o RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good report yesterday, Bleichert. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What next? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You send me back to Warrants? RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong again. But keep going. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Canvass around the Biltmore. If Red dropped her off there on the tenth maybe we can start reconstructing the last days before she got snatched. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright penny. You're doing well, Bucky. Run with the ball. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is you should keep an eye on Loew and his boys. I didn't put it in my report, but Betty sold it outright when she needed money bad enough, and Loew's been trying to keep it kiboshed so it'll look better if he ever takes it to trial. RUSS MILLARD (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You calling your boss an evidence suppressor? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a grandstanding son of a bitch. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a brighter penny than I thought. (hands him a sheet of paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty sightings. Wilshire Division. I need smart pennies to eliminate the phonies from the tip sheet. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do? MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep an eye on the evidence suppressor son of a bitch and his minions to make sure they don't try to coerce a confession out of that innocent man in the holding tank. He pats Bucky on the shoulder and walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: BUCKY CANVASSING THE WILSHIRE DISTRICT
dialogues.text: Restaurants, bars, juke joints. Bucky interviews every dr on Western and Normandie... VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barflies. Daytime juicers...The longer I listened the more they talked about themselves, interweaving their sad tales with the Black Dahlia, who they actually believed to be a glamorous siren headed for Hollywood stardom... Bucky cruises in his car into Lee and Kay's neighborhood. VOICE OVER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was as if they would have traded their own lives for a juicy front-page death. I decided my report would consist of two words: "All bullshit".

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF LEE AND KAY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bucky pulls up just as Kay storms out the door and down t steps, hurling an armful of paper onto the lawn. Lee stor beside her, shouting and waving his arms as they go back inside. Bucky walks over and kneels down besides the papers: carb of LAPD report forms, tip sheets, evidence tickets, the autopsy...all with "E. Short" typed at the top. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus. Kay and Lee come back out again, Kay tossing out more fil KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sick and it's insane! After everything...And all that might happen-- LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need this, babe. You know it. I'll rent a room for the stuff but-- (noticing Bucky)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell her Bucky. Reason with her. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right, Lee. You've pulled at least three misdemeanors here. It's out of control-- Bucky stops himself short, studying Lee's strained face. BUCKY (cont'd) (to Kay)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised him a week on it. Four more days and it's over. KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight, you can be so gutless sometimes. She turns on them both and goes back inside. Before Lee c make a wisecrack Bucky kicks his way through the LAPD pap back to his car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky sits low in his car, watching THE WHITE PACKARD par near the front of LaVerne's. He's been there awhile... Finally the woman from the night before exits and heads f her car. He jumps out and walks quickly to intercept her while she's fumbling for her keys. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slumming, Miss Sprague? She sighs, exasperated. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am now. Daddy spying on me again? She pulls a wad of cash out of her purse. Switching to a deft imitation of a Scotchman's burr: MADELEINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy, girl, ye shouldn't be congregatin' in such unsuitable places-- BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a policeman. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's a new one-- She peels off another bill. Hands it to Bucky. He counts out. Over a hundred dollars. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homicide. He hands the money back. BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try Elizabeth Short. Linda Martin. All of her bravado drops. Bucky sees it immediately. He g her purse and keys and tosses them on the hood of her car BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here or downtown? I know you knew her so don't jerk me off on that or it's downtown and a whole lot of publicity. She opens the door to her car and slides in. Bucky gets i next to her. By the roof light he can see that her simila to the Dahlia is more in her clothes and hair, but the resemblance is still there nonetheless. MADELEINE (gathering herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all a fluke. I met them at LaVerne's last fall. Betty maybe one time. Linda a couple. She'd come in to cadge a drink or a meal off a sister. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sleep with either of them? MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Just cocktail lounge chitchat. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you lez? MADELEINE (Scotchman's burr)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye might say I take it where I can find it, laddie. Bucky's charmed by her, but stays focused. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you rabbit last night? MADELEINE (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, my father is Emmett Sprague. The Emmett Sprague. He built half of Hollywood and Long Beach, and what he didn't build he bought. Imagine the headlines. "Tycoon's Daughter Questioned in Black Dahlia Case--Played Footsie with Dead Girl at Lesbian Nightclub". Get the picture? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Technicolor. (beat) What did you talk about? MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda talked about her boring boy back in Hicktown, Nebraska, or wherever. Betty talked about the latest issue of Screen World. Hollywood dreams, the sad nine yards. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty ever tell you about a movie she did? Show you a viewfinder? Anything specific? MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a conversational level they were right down there with you, only they were better looking. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cute. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not. Look, I'm tired. You want to hear my alibi so I can end this farce and go home? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all anyone ever wants to volunteer: the alibi. Go ahead. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My family and I were at our house in Laguna from Sunday through Thursday along with our live-in servants. If you want verification, call Daddy. But be discreet about where we met. She turns in the seat to face him directly. MADELEINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't suppose I can convince you to keep my name out of the papers? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need your cash if that's what you're saying. She touches his leg. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Laddie...'S not what I'm saying... He knows exactly what she's saying. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convince me. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night. Eight o'clock. My address is 482 So. Muirfield. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the address. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not surprised. Pick me up. Like a gentleman. He starts to get out of the car. MADELEINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more thing--What's your name? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky Bleichert. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try to remember. He pulls the purse off the hood and tosses her the keys. he walks away he lets out a deep breath, as if he'd been holding it the whole time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky enters and finds Lee at a desk, manning the tip pho LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. I understand. A werewolf and Red Manley. Oh no. The werewolf is Red Manley. Yes that would be more efficient... Lee dutifully writes down the crank on a routing slip. Bu slides into a chair across from him, brushing imaginary d off of the phone in front of him. Lee rings off. Smiles at Bucky. LEE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love tip duty. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...You smooth things with Kay? LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I rented a room for the stuff at the El Nido Motel. Nine scoots a week. Chump change if it makes her feel good. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De Witt gets out tomorrow, Lee. I was thinking maybe I should lean on him. Get Fritz Vogel and Koenig to do it-- Lee swings away in his rotating chair, knocking over a wastepaper basket. BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee-- The phone in front of Lee rings. He snatches it-- LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanchard. Homicide. Lee listens to the call, not saying anything. It goes on some time. Finally Bucky catches Lee's eye. Lee makes the "looney" sign with his finger. Bucky's phone rings. He picks it up. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleichert. Homicide. The person on the other line starts rambling on. Bucky ta notes diligently as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky's on another call. His pile of tip sheets and routi slips have grown. Behind him Lee pulls on his jacket and gives Bucky a two-fingered salute as he saunters out. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I logged forty-six phone tips, about half of which were reasonably coherent. Lee left early, dodging any talk about De Witt. Ellis Loew stuck me with writing up the summary report, most of which concerned the numerous dead end leads, bogus confessions and three hundred new Dahlia sightings per day. It left me gut certain of one thing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Bucky drops twenty dollars on "Unsolved - pay 2 to 1".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Short in another dress, her hair fixed differen Clapsticks come in again: "Elizabeth Short...Screen Test

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN #2 (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you from? ELIZABETH SHORT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boston. Massachusetts. MAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you lived here? ELIZABETH SHORT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years. MAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've lost your accent. ELIZABETH SHORT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, when in Rome... (looks nervously into camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Do you want a girl with an accent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky rings the bell dressed in his Sunday best blazer. Madeleine answers, a knockout in a skirt and cashmere swe MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I hate to pull this, but Daddy has heard about you. He insisted you stay for dinner. I told him we met at that art exhibit at Stanley Rose's Bookshop, so if you have to pump everybody for my alibi, be subtle. All right? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. She leads him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thick Persian carpets, tapestries, giant rooms with a men club atmosphere. Next to the fireplace Bucky notices A STUFFED SPANIEL wit yellowed newspaper rolled into its mouth. MADELEINE (re the dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Balto. The paper is the LA Times for August 1, 1926. Balto was bringing in the paper when Daddy's accountant told him he'd made his first million. Daddy wanted to consecrate the moment so he shot him. Here we go--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sprague family sits in matching easy chairs. No one stands up. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky Bleichert. May I present my family. My mother, Ramona Cathcart Sprague. My father, Emmett Sprague. My sister, Martha McConville Sprague. Emmett Sprague jumps to his feet, pumping Bucky's hand. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure, Mr. Sprague. EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw you fight Mondo Sanchez. Boxed the pants off him. Another Billy Conn you were. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mondo gave a good show. What ever happened to him? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Died of a heroin overdose. EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad. Shamed his family. (beat) Speaking of families-- Both Martha and Ramona stand up. Martha is 19, plain and serious, with a tenacious resemblance to Emmett. (Neither whom look much like Madeleine.) Ramona, on the other hand, possesses a pushing-fifty resemblance to Madeleine combined with the flaccid face a unfocused features of a booze or drug addict. RAMONA (trace of a slur)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine says nice things about you. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy can we eat? Bucky and I want to catch a nine-thirty show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black maid serves large portions of corned beef and cab EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dig in, lad. Hearty fare breeds hearty people. Haute cuisine breeds degenerates. Bucky smiles politely and begins eating. MARTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to draw Mr. Bleichert, Daddy. On Emmett's nod Martha pulls out a small sketch pad. EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in for a cruel caricaturing, Bucky. Maddy's my pretty one, but Martha's my certified genius. A wince from Martha. EMMETT SPRAGUE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of name is Bleichert? Dutch? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: German. EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great people, the Germans. Hitler was a bit excessive, but mark my words that someday we'll regret not joining forces with him to fight the Reds. I killed a lot of your countrymen during the war. MARTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you meet Balto out in the hallway? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very realistic. EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old friend stuffed him. We were in the Scots regiment together. Georgie Tilden. He wanted to work in the flickers. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when did you come here? EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1920. Hollywood was a cow pasture, but the silent flickers was booming. Georgie got work as a lighting man, and me building houses. Georgie got me introduced to Mack Sennett and I helped him build that housing project he was putting up--Hollywoodland-- underneath that godawful sign. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always loved the Keystone Kops. EMMETT SPRAGUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Mack knew how to squeeze a dollar dry, he did. He had extras moonlighting as laborers and vice versa. I used to drive 'em over to Hollywoodland after twelve hours on a Keystone Cops flicker and put in another six hours by torchlight. Even gave me as assistant director credit a couple times, so grateful he was for the way I squeezed his slaves-- A SCREECH interrupts Emmett's monologue. Bucky looks acro the table to see Ramona trying to corral a potato with he fork (the source of the sound). EMMETT SPRAGUE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother? Are you feeling well? Would you like to contribute to the conversation? Ramona forks a small bit of food and chews it daintily. RAMONA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know, Mr. Bleichert, that Ramona Boulevard was named after me? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Mrs. Sprague, I didn't. RAMONA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Emmett married me for my father's money he promised my family that he would use his influence with the City Zoning Board to have a street named after me. But all he could manage was a dead-end block in a red light district in Lincoln Heights. Are you familiar with the neighborhood, Mr. Bleichert? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up there. RAMONA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you know that the Mexican prostitutes expose themselves out of windows to attract customers. I hear many of them know Mr. Sprague by name-- Emmett Sprague SLAMS the table. Plates rattle. Silence. B stares into his lap as Madeleine grabs his knee tightly. RAMONA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sing for my supper when Mayor Bowron comes to dinner, but not for Madeleine's male whores. A common policeman. My God, Emmett. How little you think of me. She struggles to her feet and leaves the room. Her husban follows. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. MARTHA (cheery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bleichert? Martha tears a piece of paper out of her sketch pad. Buck takes it as she walks away.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKETCH
dialogues.text: A caricature of a naked Bucky having sex with Madeleine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cinderblock auto court filled with pre-war jalopies. Th camera closes on a dingy door. Room 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single yellow light illuminates the dreary flop as Buck and Madeleine fuck on the bed. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so...sorry. Don't hate my family-- don't--they're not so bad-- Bucky grabs her hair-- BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not them, me. Do me. Be with me. Focusing, Madeleine pins Bucky with her knees and pulls h deep into her until they're no longer common policeman an rich girl slut. They're one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hold each other, sweaty and spent. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I think you kept your name out of the papers. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until we announce the wedding? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother would love that. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a hypocrite. She takes pills the doctor gives her, so she's not a hophead. You know how Daddy really made his money? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bought rotten lumber and abandoned movie facades from Mack Sennett and built houses out of them. He's got firetraps all over LA registered to phony corporations...His "good friend" George? Disfigured in a car crash while running Daddy some errands. Daddy throws him scraps now--odd jobs tending some rental property-- BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to tell me this-- MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to. I like you Bucky. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you, too. She looks at him earnestly. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky, I didn't tell you all about Betty Short. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus-- MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be mad at me. It's nothing. I just don't want to lie to you. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last summer I was bar-hopping a lot. Straight bars. I heard about a girl who looked like me. I got curious and left notes at a couple places: "Your lookalike wants to meet you", things like that. I left my number. She called. That's how I met her at LaVerne's with Linda. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's all of it? MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's all of it. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then be prepared, babe. There's fifty cops out there combing every bar in town looking for Dahlia info. You could be headed for the papers no matter what. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serve my family right. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mean that. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't. He strokes her dark hair. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something. Why'd you want to meet Betty Short? MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've worked pretty hard to be loose and free. But the way people described Betty. It sounded like she was a natural. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean? MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm...She was this poor girl...Came from nothing...But then she carried nothing with her, either. I don't know...when you're rich sometimes you romanticize the poor... BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know. An awkward silence as she considers her foot in her mouth studies her for a moment. Pulls her close, kisses her mouth...the arch of her neck...They begin to move togethe again... Another LAPD FORM: "Witness Report: Lorna Martikova...aka Linda Martin..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky weaves fast through traffic. He whips a right turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky's car screeches into the parking lot just as LINDA MARTIN bursts through the doors and takes off running. Bucky jumps from the car and sprints after her, the girl clutching an oversized purse to her chest as she dashes i and out of busy traffic. The girl runs like a fucking antelope as Bucky barely mis being hit by a large BEER TRUCK and gets to the other sid the street just as Linda stumbles over a curb--sending he sprawling on the sidewalk. Bucky jumps on her, grabbing her tiny fists as she kicks screams like a hell cat. He cuffs her and pulls her up, dragging her to where she spilled her purse. LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an emancipated minor and if you touch me without a matron present I'll sue you! He picks it up her purse. Surprised by the heft, he opens and pulls out A METAL FILM CAN. Her demeanor changes instantly to fear: LINDA MARTIN (near tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, mister...My...my parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ, Harry and Bucky sit opposite Linda Martin. She's pr and small, and about to get smaller... RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you don't recall any of the names Betty went out with last fall? LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were just pickups. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one who would do her harm? The girl thinks hard, shakes her head "no". BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made the casting rounds together. Ever get any movie work? LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what about the film can? Her eyes go to the floor, tears begin to drop. LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's...a movie. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dirty movie? She nods her head silently. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to tell us the whole thing, sweetheart. So think it through. Harry pours her a paper cup of water. She takes a sip. LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was...cadging at a bar in Gardena. This Mexican man - Raoul or Jorge or something - starting talking to me. I thought I was pregnant, and I was desperate wicked bad for money. He said he'd give me two hundred dollars to act in a nudie film. She takes a large gulp of water. LINDA MARTIN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he needed another girl so I asked Betty. The three of us drove down to Tijuana and we made the movie at this big house outside of town. (beat) Then he drove us back to LA. Her head bowed. Russ and Harry stare at her impassively. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was this around Thanksgiving? She nods yes. BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the Mex give Betty a viewfinder? She raises her head in recognition and nods yes. BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he seem particularly interested in Betty? Did she see him again? She shakes her head "no". BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you saw him again, didn't you? How else could you have gotten a copy? Linda looks sadly at Bucky. LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Betty...After I read about Betty...I went looking for him in Gardena. He was about to go back to Mexico and I conned him out of a print. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was that? LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember. On Aviation somewhere. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you do that? LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Black Dahlia stag film? I thought...I could sell it if I had to. (ashamed) It was...a collector's item. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he willingly gave you a copy of the film? For nothing? LINDA MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not for nothing. She looks down again. The cops look at each other. Linda' harder and more desperate than they imagined. LINDA MARTIN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll let me have it back, won't you? You won't let people look at it? Now its the cops turn to look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ and Bucky. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whattya think? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's covering on the Mex angle. Maybe she knows him and doesn't want him taking a smut rap. Maybe he's white. The TJ stuff is sound, though. I'd detach Meg Caulfield from Wilshire Clerical to play cellmate for a day. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleichert you are a very bright penny today. (beat) Well. Looks like it's blue movie night at City Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A projector and screen has been set up. All the big-wigs present: Ellis Loew, Jack Tierney, Thad Green and Chief o Police C.B. Horrall. Millard, Harry and Lee. A clerical assistant threads the projector as Bucky settl into a seat next to Lee. On Lee's lap is a newspaper with headline: "Boulevard-Citizen's Mastermind to be Released --LA Bound after 8 years of Custody" LEE (raggedy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettin' any? Bucky's about to respond when the lights dim and a blurre image hits the screen. It begins to focus. A title: "Slave Girls From Hell" The movie: A big high-ceiling room with Egyptian hieroglyphics on the walls. Pillars shaped like coiled serpents are stationed throughout the room; the camera zo in for a close-up of two inset plaster snakes swallowing other's tails. The snakes dissolve into Betty Short, wear only stockings and doing an inept hoochie koochie dance.. An audible breath in the muster room. A hand reaches into frame, passing Betty a large cylindri object: a dildo, scales covering the shaft, fangs extendi from the circumcised head. Betty puts it in her mouth, su it, eyes wide open and glassy. An abrupt cut: Linda Martin, naked, lying on a divan. Bet enters the frame with the dildo; she puts it between Lind legs, pushing it inside her. Linda rotates her hips, tryi her best to fake ecstasy instead of pain and sadness. Another cut: Betty mouthing the words "No, please" to the camera. A hand pushing her head down towards Linda's crot Betty tonguing next to the dildo...

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON THE MUSTER ROOM
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is somber, but calm. The film continues... CHIEF HORRALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whattya think, Russ? This got anything to do with the girl's murder-- RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long shot, Chief. Harry and I are headed down to TJ tonight. The Mex doesn't play as the killer. But maybe he showed it to someone-- Suddenly Lee jumps up, standing in front of the screen. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gives a fuck if he didn't kill her! I've sent Boy Scouts to the green room for less than this! He yanks down the screen with a crash and storms out of t room. The movie continues on the chalked up blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee sits on the ground, head in his hands. Bucky enters a sits on a bench next to him. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see her face, Bucky? Did you see? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I did, partner. I did. Bucky notices Lee's still clutching the De Witt article i his fist. He pries it loose. Ellis Loew and Russ Millard enter. ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit, Blanchard! I got you Warrants. You're my man, and you made me look like a fool in front of the two most powerful men in the Department. If you weren't Mr. Fire you'd be suspended from duty already. You've gotten personally involved in the Short case-- BUCKY (holding up the newspaper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Loew, it's not just Betty Short-- ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Bleichert. (back to Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're back on Warrants as of tomorrow. Report to me at 0800 with letters of apology for Green and Horrall. For the sake of your pension I'd suggest you grovel. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go to TJ-- ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanchard! Poison hangs in the air. Ellis turns on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky sits in his cubicle searching the Dahlia files. The clock behind him reads "12:30". Loew approaches. ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been skating around all morning, Bleichert. Vogel and Koenig went to Tijuana an hour ago so I need you to check out a radio car and get out there. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you see that phantom partner of yours, tell him this no-show's gonna cost him three days pay. Loew walks off. Bucky dials the phone. MADELEINE (VO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. You want to get together? MADELEINE (VO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pick you up in forty-five minutes. MADELEINE (VO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at the house. Daddy's having a business soiree. The Red Arrow. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an apartment, you know. MADELEINE (VO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room 11. Forty-five minutes. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lie naked in the bed. Bucky's lost in thought. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile at me. Look soft and sweet. He looks anything but. BUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They picked up Linda Martin yesterday. She had a stag film of her and Betty Short playing lez. Spooky stuff. Madeleine sits up. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she mention me? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. And I checked through the case file. There's no mention of that note-leaving number you pulled. (beat) Babe, I'm withholding evidence for you. It's a fair trade for what I'm getting, but it still shakes me. Is there anything you haven't told me about Betty and Linda? She runs her fingers down his ribcage, teasing his boxing scars. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar, Betty and I made love once, that one time we met last summer. I just did it to see what it would be like to do it with someone who looked like me and-- BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. He jumps from the bed and pulls on his pants. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky that's it, I swear. Please stay-- He pulls on his shirt, his handcuffs and his .38. Grabs h jacket-- MADELEINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay sugar stay-- --and slams the door on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky steamed in the car. He flips on the police radio, looking for distraction. Instead he gets: RADIO DISPATCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Code four all units at Crenshaw and Stocker. Two dead, suspect dead, Raymond Douglas Nash, warrant number--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAYMOND NASH lies dead on the sidewalk. Off to one side, short and wiry cop is describing for detectives how it al went down, pantomiming how he shot an escaping Raymond Na Bucky stands over Nash, staring at his dead features. He walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky's POV: A robbery gone bad. A sixty-year old Korean shopowner lie dead behind the counter and his teenaged son lies dead in aisle. Blood and green linoleum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky bursts into the squad room, seeing red. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanchard! A cop walking through the bullpen points to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky kicks in the door, finding Lee washing his hands in sink. He holds his hands up to Bucky, blood oozes from Le knuckles. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beat up a wall. Penance for Nash. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough. Bucky steps into Lee with fists flying, a mad demon. He smashes him again and again, beating his only friend unti Lee slides senseless to the floor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky drinks bourbon straight, his wrist heavily bandaged VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Losing the first Bleichert-Blanchard fight got me local celebrity, Warrants, and close to nine grand in cash; winning the rematch got me a sprained wrist, two dislocated knuckles and the rest of the day off. Whoever said winning isn't everything got that part right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky walks into the house and finds Kay there. She holds a newspaper: The front page includes The Black Dahlia, Ju Nash, and Bobby De Witt. KAY (eyes red from crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're famous, Dwight. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notorious, maybe. Where's Lee? KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen him since you beat him up. Bucky looks ashamed. KAY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you. He walks to her and she holds him. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in trouble, you know. She nods. He strokes her hair. BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De Witt's probably in LA by now. If Lee doesn't show up by tonight I'll come over to stay with you. KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you coming over here just to sleep an the couch again. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay. Lee-- She holds up a hand, waving him off. She knows all this. KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Dwight? Fighting, cops, guns. To most people--that's the scary stuff. Not everything else. She knows him to the core. She steps back, holding his ha KAY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luck. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short of winning? KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky's on the phone. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. He rings off looking very disturbed as Russ and Harry arr BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened in TJ? HARRY SEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checked for the smut pad. Goose egg. Peddlers--double goose egg-- RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky. Blanchard's in Tijuana. A border cop spotted him hobnobbing with a bunch of rough-looking Rurales last night. Bucky exhales hard. RUSS MILLARD (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? BUCKY (re his phone call)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was County Parole. Bobby DeWitt bought a bus ticket at the Santa Rosa depot this morning. San Diego. Transfer Tijuana.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: Bucky cruises the Tijuana streets: child beggars dig for  breakfast in trash cans, taco venders stir pots of dog-me stew, sailors and marines stumble out of whorehouses. Rur drive prewar Chevys wearing black uniforms... VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in LA, Linda Short let slip that her "Mex" was actually a local named Walter Wellington, who copped to making the film but quickly provided the cops his alibi for the Dahlia's missing days. Bucky parks at a big pink Art Deco hotel (The Divisidero)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky badges the desk clerk and gets a room number. He he upstairs. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that this stopped Loew and his boys from rousting spics all over town for a possible Dahlia frame-up. The circus was becoming a farce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellis Loew, Fritz Vogel, and Bill Koenig arguing. ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't do that! Wellington told Tierney he made the pic-- Bucky opens the door and the room falls quiet. ELLIS LOEW (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleichert. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee's down here and so is Bobby De Witt. ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck Blanchard. He's suspended. Bucky charges the DA but Vogel and Koenig intercept him, pushing him roughly back out in the hall. Loew retreats t the other side of the room. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, kid? I got a soft spot in my heart for light heavyweights. (chucks his chin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promise not to hit Billy and I'll help you look for your partner. (re Bucky's ragged appearance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drive. You look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky and Fritz Vogel drive past beggars swarming tourist hookers dispensing front seat blow jobs, zoot suit youths prowling for drunks to roll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men park the car in the middle of a car-choked st and decide to try walking. They're immediately swallowed by kid beggars shoving crucifixes in their faces. Bucky tosses handfuls of coins into the gutters and the children scatter, squabbling over the coins.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACKGROUND
dialogues.text: Fritz Vogel approaches a Rurale and talks to him. The Rur nods yes, gesturing down an alley to a squat cinderblock building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogel and Bucky walk quickly down a corridor lined with e cells. A Mexican jailer unlocks the last cell and the two cops walk in to face

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY DEWITT
dialogues.text: the hatchet-faced tough of 1939 now a grizzled and bloate well-used piece of work. He stands up, full of con bravad DEWITT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops, huh? Well at least you're American. Never thought I'l be glad to see you guys. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why start now? Vogel kicks in the balls, dropping him to his knees. Voge smashes him with a thick backhand across the face.

dialogues.speaker: BUCKY HANDCUFFING BOBBY DEWITT TO A CHAIR
dialogues.text: Vogel stands over him. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee Blanchard's here in TJ, and you came here flush out of Big Q. That's a goddamned strange coincidence and I don't like it. I don't like you and I don't like being down in this rat-infested country when I could be home with my family. DeWitt pisses his pants. VOGEL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know Blanchard was in TJ? DEWITT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't seen Blanchard since my fuckin' trial. Vogel smashes him across the face. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not use profanity with me, and address me as sir. DeWitt's head bobs up and down. VOGEL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Blanchard's scared of you. Why? DEWITT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man o Manieschewitz, what a laugh. Lee beauty gotta be scared of me 'cause of how I flapped my trap at trial, but all I know is what I read in the papers. Maybe I was thinkin' revenge, maybe talkin' trash to my cellies, but when Lee beauty killed them niggers-- Vogel topples DeWitt with a right hook and then picks him back up by the neck, squeezing the life out of him. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby boy I do not like Sergeant Blanchard but he is a fellow officer and I will not have syphilitic scum like you defaming him. Now you risked a parole violation for a trip down here. He lets go of his neck, the color returning to DeWitt's f VOGEL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here, Bobby. You tell me. DEWITT (a beaten dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came down to cop some heroin and move it back to LA. I'm meeting a guy, Felix Casco, at the Gardena Motel. Please. Don't hurt me no more. Please. Vogel claps his hands together, gleeful with this bonus b VOGEL (heading out of the cell)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna call Ellis. Bucky turns back to De Witt, who's much more relaxed now Vogel's left the cell. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish up with you and Blanchard. DEWITT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, all that's between me and Blanchard is that I fucked this cunt Kay Lake--

dialogues.speaker: IN SLOW MOTION--
dialogues.text: Bucky leaps on De Witt, grabbing him around the neck and choking him. De Witt turns blue, his eyes bulging out--

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND BUCKY, VOICES IN SPANISH
dialogues.text: and then hands on his shoulders as Ducky is hurled backwa into the cell bars. And then

dialogues.speaker: BLACKNESS
dialogues.text: which slowly becomes grey, and then back to normal as Buc finds himself awakening on the floor of the cell. Refocusing on the scene: Two Rurales in jodhpur boots pick their teeth with matchsticks as Fritz Vogel pulls Bucky to his feet. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long-- VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I let Bobby boy go so we could tail him to his pal. But he blew his tail while you were catching up on your beauty sleep, which is too bad for him.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE STUDEBAKER
dialogues.text: Vogel, Koenig, a Rurale, and Bucky (holding a piece of ic the back of his head). The car arrives at a horseshoe-shaped auto court. Two Mex policeman stand guard outside one of its rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the American cops walk in on a cordite-reeking slaughterhouse. Bobby De Witt and a Mexican man lay dead the floor, bullet holes oozing blood all over them. Bucky notes the bruises on De Witt's neck from where he choked him. Bucky squints at the men, still a little disoriented... VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spic's Felix Casco, a known dope trafficker. Maybe it was other dope scum, maybe Lee, maybe it was God. I say let our Mexican colleagues handle their own dirty laundry and we go back to LA and find the son of a bitch who sliced the Dahlia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay sits curled into a corner of the couch, defensively. Bucky sits on a small chair next to Lee's large easy chai KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent the morning with Internal Affairs. I told them...everything I knew. I gave them so much...and in the end it didn't seem like anything at all. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll came back, Kay. I'm sure of it. KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know anything, Dwight. But that's what I like about you. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay-- KAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been offered a job. Teaching sixth grade at Fairfax Primary. With Lee gone now-- BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming back. She nods, mollifying him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Bucky jimmies the lock and pushes open the door.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE ROOM 204
dialogues.text: Boxes of police falls scattered on the bed and desk. Phot of Elizabeth Short pinned up all over the walls: glamour glossies, newspaper photos, enlarged crime scene grotesquerie. The amount of manpower represented here is staggering; so much work over one girl. Bucky sits down at the desk and buries his head in his ha BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee.

dialogues.speaker: FRITZ VOGEL AND BUCKY
dialogues.text: interviewing a fortysomething TALENT AGENT in a slick sui He sits at a desk with yellowed starlets' headshots behin him. Vogel leans on the desk, intimidating the man. AGENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...okay, yeah. So I got her name from a producer friend of mine. Met her in a bar...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 204
dialogues.text: Russ Millard and Harry Sears stand goggle-eyed as Bucky s them Lee's back-up files... VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to believe it was all about Lee. Tracking Lee through her...through the files he had collected.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS MILLARD
dialogues.text: meticulously sifting through the material along with Buck

dialogues.speaker: A PHOTO OF ELIZABETH SHORT DRESSED IN BLACK
dialogues.text: VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strangers' recollections of a girl's last days leading me to a partner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRITZ VOGEL AND BUCKY interviewing a HOOKER in a hotel lobby... HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the other girls and me, we helped her out once in a while. Throw her a trick if she needed dough...But she was no pro.

dialogues.speaker: KAY AND LEE'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: where Bucky watches Kay grade papers, a gulf between them

dialogues.speaker: AN AUTOPSY PHOTO OF ELIZABETH SHORT
dialogues.text: VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the deeper into her I got, the more I understood the detective's old saw: any dick worth his suit always takes a side: the perp or the vic.

dialogues.speaker: 39TH ANMD NORTON
dialogues.text: where Bucky stands in the empty lot, alone. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most cops'll tell ya...one day you wake up and you're in the head of the killer...Angry. Powerful. In control. You're the perp.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTAGE FROM BETTY AND LINDA'S PORN FILM
dialogues.text: as the camera dances across Betty Short's naked body. WE CLOSE IN on her, the 16mm film becoming finer and finer a the sex scene transforms into A LIVE SHOT OF BETTY SHORT, writhing in ecstasy underneat man. She and the man fuck harder and harder, faster and faster. BETTY SHORT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...Please...

dialogues.speaker: BUCKY'S FACE
dialogues.text: groaning with the ecstasy of ejaculation--

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON BETTY SHORT BENEATH HIM-
dialogues.text: but it's not Betty Short. It's Madeleine Sprague, staring at Bucky as the two of them come simultaneously. As soon as it's over, she looks for his eyes. He won't lo at her. She grabs his chin and turns him face to face. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Few cops'll admit to walking the harder path...fear...pain...loss...Few will admit to waking up in the head of the vic. He lower his face to the pillow...

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANOTHER CASTING SESSION
dialogues.text: Another clapstick: "Elizabeth Short...Screen test #3" Elizabeth Short, looking a bit more worn down, holds a sc up to her face. ELIZABETH SHORT (reading stiffly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't just walk out on me, Richard. Say something. Say you care say you-- MAN #3 (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. There's a pause there. She stops, frustrated. MAN #3 (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe with a little more sadness. Can you give me a little more sadness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the "UNSOLVED" sheet at the LAPD betting pool. Handwritte on the sheet are the constantly dropping odds: "2 to 1" replaced by "3 to 2" which has been replaced by "Even Money".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "TRANSFER NOTICE...As of 2/6/47 these officers currently assigned to the Elizabeth Short investigation will return to their regular duties...

dialogues.speaker: THE SCENE
dialogues.text: as Bucky reads the list. Unfortunately his name is not on He beelines straight to

dialogues.speaker: RUSS MILLARD'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: the quiet man looks up from his desk. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't on the transfer list. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked Jack to keep you on. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're getting to be a damn good Detective, Bleichert. And Harry's retiring in two years. Need I spell it out? BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been working this case pretty hard. Or is it the other way around? Bucky smiles weakly; Russ knows him. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not as much fun once it moves to the back pages, is it? (changing subjects) I hear they arrested two Mexicans in Juarez for the Bobby De Witt murder. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard that, too. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be relieved. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've rescinded the APB on Lee. If he doesn't show up in thirty days he's out. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be found if he wants to be found. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the guy who killed the Dahlia? Russ smiles grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky rings the doorbell. Fritz Vogel answers. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boyo! Glad you could make it. He claps Bucky on the shoulder and leads him into the hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior decorating equivalent of highballs and pretz which is exactly what Vogel, Bucky and Ellis Loew are consuming. Bucky drinks with the trepidation of the King' food taster. ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called this little meeting for a couple reasons, Bucky. We'd both like to see the Short case closed out and get back to normal business. Bucky looks impatient and Ellis senses this. ELLIS LOEW (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're both comers, Bucky. Fritzie wants you for his partner when he gets his lieutenancy, and-- BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ Millard wants me when Harry retires. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too raw for him, boyo. Old Russ is a sob sister, and I'm much more your type. Bucky considers the truth in this. To Loew: BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Ellis? ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, Dwight. I'll tell you. There are four confessors still being held at City Jail. They've got no alibis, weren't coherent when they were first questioned, and they're all violent, frothing-at-the- mouth lunatics. I want them reintegrated. It's a muscle job. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted Bill Koenig-- ELLIS LOEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Bill's a bit too enamored with violence. So it's you, Dwight. Yes or no? Because if it's yes, I'll make sure you're back on Warrants tomorrow with an inside track to some stripes. If not, it's Homicide shitwork until Russ Millard gets tired of you. We both know that Russ is a patient, forbearing man, Dwight. That could be a long time. Yes or no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as four manacled men are being loaded into a drunk wagon while Bucky flips through their rap sheets and mug shots.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE DRUNK WAGON
dialogues.text: the four men sit in the back as Bucky drives the truck. T camera pans their faces. The first, LOREN BIDWELL, pale, and palsied. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On my way over I played out their rap sheets in my head, trying to work up a head of hate...Loren Bidwell, three time Atascadero loser, falls for aggravated sexual assault on minors. Between prison jolts he confessed to all the big sex crimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky pulls the drunk wagon up to a building, its street facade illuminated: "KOUNTY KING LUNCH MEAT--SERVING L.A. COUNTY WITH INSTITUTIONAL FOOD SINCE 1923"... THE CAMERA finds the second man, CECIL DURKIN. VOICE OVER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil Durkin--hophead, knife fighter and a jailhouse rape-o who played jazz drums with some good combos. He took two Quentin jolts for Arson and was caught masturbating at the scene of his last torch.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FRONT OF THE WAREHOUSE BUILDING
dialogues.text: Fritz Vogel opens the door and leads the men inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge sawdust-covered roam, meathooks dangling from the ceiling. Beef dangles over half the hooks. The four men l terrified. The camera finds the third man, CHARLIE ISSLER: VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie Issler was a pimp and a career confessor specializing in copping to hooker homicides. His three procuring beefs had netted him a year county jail time, his phony confessions two ninety day observation stints at the Camarillo nut farm. And the fourth man, PAUL ORCHARD: VOICE OVER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally Paul Orchard. Jack roller, male prostitute, and a former San Bernardino County deputy sheriff. The group reaches a back wall of the warehouse where FOUR UNUSED MEATHOOKS DANGLE OVER FOUR CHAIRS. Bucky studies the men's apprehensive faces as Vogel stand each one on a chair with their manacled hands hooked over their respective meathooks. Bucky's gaze drifts back behind a large box where he sees SHEET-COVERED TABLE sticking out. Before his curiosity dr him over Vogel addresses the prisoners. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all confessed to killing the Dahlia. We can't prove you did, so you're gonna have to convince us... Query on, Bucko. Bucky takes a deep breath and heads first to old man Bidw The man's palsy has him shaking and Bucky grabs the meath above him to steady him. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about Betty Short, pops. Why'd you kill her? Bidwell looks at him with beseeching eyes. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be timid, boyo. That bird made little boys suck his hog. Bucky's hand twitches on the meathook. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come clean, pop. BIDWELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't kill her mister. I just wanted a ticket to the honor farm. Three hots and a cot, that's all. Please, mister. The man's weakened state makes his argument for him. Buck moves on to Cecil Durkin. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it, Cecil. DURKIN (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get that line from Dick Tracy or Gangbusters? Bucky catches Vogel out of the corner of his eye. Measuri BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more time, shitbird. Tell me about you and Betty Short. DURKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fucked Betty Short and I fucked your mama! I'm your fucking daddy! Bucky one-two's him in the solar plexus. His legs buckle, he keeps his feet on the chair. DURKIN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you clever, don't you. You the bad guy, your buddy the nice guy. Older than vaudeville. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the nice guy, Cecil. Keep that in mind. This shuts Durkin up. Bucky moves to Charlie Issler. ISSLER (sincere)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. I didn't kill Liz. I don't know why I do these things, and I apologize. So please don't let that man hurt me. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convince me. ISSLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...can't. I just can't. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a pimp. You know Betty Short? ISSLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you confess to her murder? ISSLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looked so...sweet and pretty and I felt so bad. I always confess to the pretty ones. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel guilty Charlie? You hit your girls, get 'em high on hop? ISSLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do such nasty things I don't know why-- Vogel struts over, putting on brass knuckles. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kid glove routine's gettin' old-- He kicks Issler's chair out from under him, the pimp screaming as his wrists snap. Vogel kicks the remaining t chairs out, punctuating each with a declaration: VOGEL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack roller! Nigger! Baby fucker! The men scream like dying animals as Fritzie zeroes in on Charlie Issler. He begins punching him in the gut with th brass knuckles. VOGEL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about the Dahlia's missing days you whoremonger! Tell me! ISSLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...don't...know...anything! VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what you know! He punches him in the crotch. ISSLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you at Ad Vice! Vogel ignores him, rabbit punching him, cracking one rib then another--

dialogues.speaker: ON BUCKY'S FACE
dialogues.text: knowing this is getting out of control. He's mesmerized b FIRE ALARM on the wall behind the men... VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what your girls tell you! Issler retches, coughing up blood. Bucky stares at the fi alarm as Fritz runs through his field of vision, cackling Bucky refocuses on the scene as Fritzie returns, wheeling sheet-covered table Bucky'd seen before. He whips off the sheet revealing:

dialogues.speaker: THE DAHLIA.
dialogues.text: Vogel grabs Issler by the scruff of the neck and jerks hi down off of the meathook. VOGEL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your cutting pleasure, Jane Doe number forty-three. You're all going to slice her, and the best slicer buys the ticket! Issler bites through his lip as Fritzie pulls out a switchblade and pops it open. Bucky takes in the nightmare scene all in slow-motion, th men with their broken wrists, the pudgy naked corpse, Fri with the knife... He runs for the fire alarm and pulls the lever, a piercin bell ringing out as Bucky runs out of the warehouse and j into the drunk wagon, tearing off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay answers the door and finds Bucky sitting on the front porch, sobbing. She moves to him, touching him on the back of the neck, t stroke of her finger enough to make him stand and face he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky tries to talk but she puts fingers to his mouth. Mo to his fingers. She undresses him. Slowly she touches him easing him, bringing him back to earth, back to humanity. her. And finally they are joined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER TYPEWRITTEN SHEET: "LAPD Transfer orders: Officer Dwight Bleichert...From: Central Warrants...To: Foot Patrol, Swingwatch. Central Station..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky picks his way through passed-out drunks and bums. H back in uniform. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: East 5th Street from Main to Stanford. Blood banks, liquor stores selling half pints and short dogs exclusively, fifty- cent-a-night flophouses and derelict missions...

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE STREET
dialogues.text: two officers brutally herd winos into a drunk wagon. Buck turns and walks the other direction, refusing to help. Th see him and sneer. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banished by Ellis Loew, who dared me to try my word against a twenty-two year man and the city's future District Attorney. I confined the truth to Russ and Kay, and determined to spend my shifts trying to be the worst foot hack in history. He hands a quarter to a drunk as he passes, urging him wi his nightstick to crawl back into a bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ Millard pores over a file in their private collectio Bucky sits with his feet up on the bed, flipping through folder... VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A month passed. The Dahlia leads dwindled to zero and every officer except Russ and Harry were returned to their regular assignments. As for me, I'd been able to contain my Dahlia interests within the walls of the El Nido. Bucky eyes a Dahlia photo pinned to the wall. VOICE OVER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, I remembered what Madeleine said when I told her we were through...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine sits on the bed fully dressed. Bucky stands in doorway. MADELEINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be back. (beat) I look like her. Bucky turns and leaves as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where Kay and Bucky sleep in bed, locked as spoons. Safe. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sometimes Betty came to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky watches Fritz Vogel beats the hell out of Charles Issler as he hangs off the meathook. In the background, B Short stands and screams: BETTY SHORT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky! No! Stop him! (crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do whatever you want... ISSLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be okay....Liz... Bucky turns and stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: BUCKY'S BLAZING EYES
dialogues.text: MILLARD (VO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Bucky stares across the room at a picture of the Dahli Millard sits at the small desk, waiting for him to come b RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky. Bucky finally sees Russ again. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever hear anyone refer to Betty as Liz? Anyone at all? RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Issler did. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pimp? I thought he said he'd never heard of her. BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what else he said?

dialogues.speaker: A FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: As Vogel cracks Issler's ribs. VOGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you know about the Dahlia's missing days? ISSLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you at Ad Vice--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry Sears cradles the phone in his ear as he flips thro a large metal file cabinet. Behind him the glass door rea in reverse: "ADMINISTRATIVE VICE'. HARRY SEARS (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N-n-no, Russ. No file on Issler. Gone.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE EL NIDO
dialogues.text: Bucky and Russ sit in silence, thinking. They know they'r onto something... BUCKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fritzie didn't give a damn about those other three. It was all about Issler. Never occurred to me before. Bucky gets to his feet. BUCKY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet me back here. Late. RUSS MILLARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright penny-- But Bucky's already out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky stakes out the dark house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky slips an oil dipstick into the narrow crack of the door and flips the simple hook and eyehole lock. He slide into the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Bucky creeps through the house until he gets to a clos door. He opens it, entering

dialogues.speaker: FRITZIE'S STUDY
dialogues.text: He stumbles along the wall until he finds a standing gooseneck lamp and turns it on. The walls are covered wit pictures of Fritzie in uniform, dating back twenty-five years. Bucky bends down in front of the small mahogany desk and begins rifling through its file drawers. What he finds surprises him: --carbons of official LAPD intelligence reports, lists of account balances, financial dealings, payments made--all  cross-referenced to each individual being investigated.
